# Helios Project Roadmap

> **TL;DR**
>
> - **4 phases:** R&D (1-6+ years, parallel) -> Earth (2-4) -> Moon (4-6) -> Mercury (6-10)
> - **Total budget:** $350-750 billion; peak personnel ~50K people
> - **Launches to Moon:** 10-20 (technology validation)
> - **Launches to Mercury:** ~900 (building ~1650 factories)
> - **Key risk:** Track 1 (robots and factories) - new technologies; Track 2 (rockets) - proven experience

From first blueprints to 1000 Mass Drivers on Mercury.

Detailed calculations: [Mirrors and Energy](../detailed/mirrors.qmd#energy) | [Mass Drivers](../detailed/production/railguns/theory.qmd) | [Budget](budget.qmd)

---

## Two Parallel Tracks

| Track | Complexity | Experience |
|-------|------------|------------|
| **1. Robots and factories** | High | New technologies |
| **2. Rocket program** | Medium | Decades of country experience |

**Track 2** - scaling proven technologies. Countries know how to build rockets.

**Track 1** - the main challenge. Requires phased validation.

### Phase 1: R&D and Development (years 1-6+)

**Parallel phase:** R&D starts in year 1 and continues throughout the preparation period (until year 6+). Technology development runs in parallel with testing on Earth (years 2-4) and Moon (years 4-6). Design, simulations, AI development do not stop until full Mercury readiness is achieved.

**Budget: $15-30B | Peak: 30-50K people**

#### Years 1-2: Intensive Design (peak load)

| Direction | Budget ($B) | People |
|-----------|-------------|--------|
| Swarm control software | 6-10 | 12-20K |
| Autonomy neural networks | 4-8 | 8-15K |
| VR simulators | 2-4 | 4-8K |
| Scientific research | 2-4 | 3-6K |

**For comparison:** SpaceX ~13K, Waymo ~2.5K, NVIDIA ~30K employees.

#### Years 3-6: Refinements and Validation (parallel with proving grounds)

**Focus evolution:**

| Period | Work Focus | Personnel |
|--------|-----------|-----------|
| **Years 3-4** | Refinements based on Earth proving ground results | 20-30K |
| **Years 5-6** | Refinements based on Moon proving ground results | 10-20K |

**Main directions in years 3-6:**
- **Algorithm optimization** based on real proving ground data
- **Fixing identified problems** in factory and robot prototypes
- **Autonomy AI refinement** for real conditions (communication delays, unforeseen situations)
- **VR simulator adaptation** for space conditions (temperature, radiation, dust)
- **Technical documentation preparation** for Mercury

**Staff reduction:** As main design completes (years 1-2), the team gradually shrinks. Only engineers working on refinements and validation based on proving ground data remain.

#### Ground Zero Factory Design

::: {.callout-note}
## Goal and Calculation Status

The goal of this documentation is to confirm the **fundamental feasibility** of the project and provide preliminary budget and timeline estimates. Calculations confirm: all necessary technologies exist ([MRE electrolysis](../reference/technology-readiness.qmd#mre-molten-regolith-electrolysis), [WAAM](../reference/technology-readiness.qmd#waam-wire-arc-additive-manufacturing), solar concentration, [electromagnetic launch](../reference/technology-readiness.qmd#electromagnetic-launch-mass-driver)), materials on Mercury are present in sufficient quantities (Al, Fe, Si, Ti, S), delivery logistics are realistic at current launch cost trends.

All provided numbers (areas, productivities, material flows) are **preliminary order-of-magnitude estimates**. Transitioning to implementation requires work by a professional engineering team to refine parameters, detailed design, and validation of adopted decisions.
:::

The project's key unit is the **replicator factory (F-R)**, fully self-sufficient for building new factories ([lights-out factories TRL 9](../reference/technology-readiness.qmd#lights-out-factories)). The second type - **mirror factory (F-M)** - specializes in mirror production.

**Replicator factory (F-R) structure:**
- Dome: 1500 m^2^ (50x30 m), height 6-8 m, atmosphere 0.1 atm N~2~
- Zones: foundry, rolling, drawing, forming (WAAM+CNC), robot assembly, dome cutting/welding, equipment assembly
- Productivity: 5 robots/day, 1 dome / 2-3 days, 1 equipment set / 2-3 weeks

**Mirror factory (F-M):**
- Same dome (1500 m^2^), different specialization
- Zones: foundry, foil rolling, mirror assembly, QC/packaging
- Productivity: ~400 mirrors/day

> **More details:** [Factory Production](../detailed/production/factories/overview.qmd)

#### Regolith Processing Line Design

**Fiberglass line:**
- MRE electrolysis -> silicate melt -> Pt-Rh spinnerets -> 28 t/day fiber
- Application: composite domes for factories
- [Details: fiberglass line](../detailed/production/materials/silicate-fabric.qmd)

**Titanium line:**
- TiO~2~ electrolysis -> PVD deposition -> electrochromic coating for mirrors
- Application: mirror orientation control without fuel
- [Details: titanium line](../detailed/production/materials/titanium.qmd)

**Continuous slag distillation:**
- Al/Mg/Na/K separation at different boiling temperatures
- Application: obtaining pure metals for production
- [Details: distillation](../detailed/production/materials/distillation.qmd)

> **More details:** [Regolith Processing Overview](../detailed/production/materials/overview.qmd)

#### Material Production Line Design

**Aluminum line:**
- Continuous casting for 50 um foil -> mirrors and concentrators
- [Details: aluminum line](../detailed/production/materials/distillation.qmd)

**Iron line:**
- Producing rods for robot frames and MD structures
- [Details: iron line](../detailed/production/materials/mre.qmd)

**Silicate line:**
- Loom + laminator -> 8-layer composite for domes
- [Details: silicate line](../detailed/production/materials/silicate-fabric.qmd)

#### Assembly Line Design

**Mirror assembly (F-M):**
- ~400 mirrors/day (116 kg each)
- 4 um Al foil + TiO~2~ electrochromic coating
- [Details: mirror assembly](../detailed/mirrors.qmd)

**Gen-2 robot assembly (F-R):**
- 5 robots/day (960 kg each)
- 99% local materials (Al frames + Fe assemblies), 1% "Vitamins" from Earth
- [Details: robot assembly](../detailed/production/robots/overview.qmd)

**Dome assembly:**
- 8-layer composite (fabric + Al foil) for factory atmosphere
- [Details: dome assembly](../detailed/production/factories/assembly/domes.qmd)

#### Factory Equipment Assembly Line Design

**For self-replication:** each factory produces equipment for new factories.

**Regolith processing line:**
- MRE cells (electrolyzers) - steel/ceramic body, iridium anodes (import)
- Solar furnaces - Al concentrators (local)
- Distillation induction furnaces - Al+Cu coils
- [Details: regolith processing](../detailed/production/materials/overview.qmd)

**Material production line:**
- CC-Al, CC-Fe (continuous casting machines) - Fe frame, Cu crystallizers (import)
- 6-stand rolling mills - Fe rolls, local drive
- Drawing mills - tungsten dies (import)
- Looms - for silicate fabric, Al+Fe body
- Laminators - for 8-layer dome composite
- [Details: aluminum line](../detailed/production/materials/distillation.qmd)
- [Details: iron line](../detailed/production/materials/mre.qmd)
- [Details: silicate line](../detailed/production/materials/silicate-fabric.qmd)

**Assembly line:**
- PVD chambers - for TiO~2~ deposition on mirrors, steel body
- [WAAM](../reference/technology-readiness.qmd#waam-wire-arc-additive-manufacturing) equipment (3D printing) - for Gen-2 robot frames
- 5-axis CNC milling centers - Fe body, spindle (import)
- Assembly jigs - for Gen-2 robots

**99% local materials:**
- Equipment frames: Fe (local)
- Bodies, cladding: Al (local)
- Furnace lining: MgO ceramics (local)
- Heat transfer fluids: NaK alloy (Na+K local)

**1% critical imports:**
- Iridium anodes for MRE (~10 kg/year per cell)
- Pt-Rh spinnerets for fiberglass (~50-100 kg/year)
- Copper crystallizers for continuous casting (high thermal conductivity)
- Tungsten dies and cutters (~0.1 t/year)
- Bearings, drives, electronics

> **More details:** [Factory Self-Replication](../detailed/production/factories/assembly/replication.qmd)

**Each F-R produces ~83 t for a new factory** (dome 8 t + equipment 51 t + robots 14 t + power system 10 t), enabling exponential growth: 1 -> 2 -> 4 -> ... -> ~1650 factories in ~4 years.

#### Ground Zero Factory - Space Version

**Differences from Earth prototype:**
- Radiation protection (cosmic rays, solar flares)
- Vacuum seals for domes
- Thermal regulation: -180C (night) to +120C (day)

**What we test:**
- Full cycle: robots -> factory assembly -> Gen-2 production
- Lunar regolith mining and processing
- Autonomous operation (1.3 sec communication delay)
- All production line validation in space

#### LSP Station Development

**Lunar Solar Power** - receiving and transmitting energy from Swarm to Earth:

**Location:** Moon limbs (east + west)
- Earth visibility: constant
- Reception from Swarm: mirror clusters focus light

**Technology:**
1. Concentrated light reception from Swarm
2. PV panels (GaAs, 30% efficiency)
3. Conversion to 2.45 GHz microwaves
4. Transmission to rectenna on Earth

**Chain efficiency:**
- Swarm -> LSP: 95% (reflection + light transmission)
- LSP PV: 30% (light -> electricity)
- Electricity -> microwaves: 80%
- Microwaves -> Earth: 75%
- **Total: 18%** (vs 10% for orbital hub)

**LSP advantages:**
- Heat goes into ground (no radiators needed in space)
- Stable position (no station-keeping required)
- Repair and maintenance by factory robots

**Number of stations:** 20-40
- Coverage: 24/7 reception from one station
- Redundancy: system works if 1-2 stations fail

> **More details:** [Energy Reception Hub: LSP](../detailed/hub.qmd)

#### Test Mass Driver on Moon

**Parameters:**
- Track length: 1-1.5 km
- Target velocity: 2.5 km/s (Moon escape velocity)
- Payload mass: 116 kg (test mirror)

**Test program:**
- Inert dummy launches (100-200 launches)
- Real mirror launches (50-100 launches)
- Orbital deployment verification
- Electrochromic control

**Result:**
- MD validation for Mercury
- Vacuum wear database
- Space mirror coordination experience

> **More details:** [Mass Driver: Calculations](../detailed/production/railguns/theory.qmd)

#### Energy Transmission to Earth (first test)

**Goal:** verify full LSP -> Earth chain

**Program:**
- Launch 10-100 mirrors from lunar MD
- Form test cluster
- Focus on one LSP station
- Transmit microwaves to rectenna (Nevada/Yakutia)

**Test power:**
- 100 mirrors x 93 MW x 0.18 = 1.67 GW to Earth
- Enough for a city of ~1.5 million people

**Test result:**
- Proof of concept for full system
- Public demonstration (political support)
- Validation before Mercury

**Lunar proving ground advantages:**
- Errors are cheap - lost a lunar mission, not Mercurian
- Fast iterations - 3 days to Moon
- Public success - energy to Earth already at this stage

**Phase result:** Validated system (factory + MD + LSP + Swarm), ready for Mercury.

### Track 2: Rocket Program (parallel with Phases 1-3, years 1-6)

| Year | Tasks |
|------|-------|
| 1-2 | Carrier selection, manufacturer contracts |
| 2-4 | Spaceport modernization (Baikonur, Vostochny, partners) |

**Note:** The rocket industry - organic development. These capacities would develop anyway: commercial launches, satellite constellations, lunar programs. ## Mercury Strategy: Test + Reinforcement

**Principle:** First we verify, then we scale.

| Stage | Cargo | Goal | Risk |
|-------|-------|------|------|
| Expedition 1 | 75 t | Test: 1 factory + 1 MD | If failure - lost 75 t |
| Expedition 2 | 150 t | Reinforcement: +3 factories | Only after E1 success |

**Advantages:**
- Risk reduction: not putting all eggs in one basket
- Acceleration: 4 factories instead of 1 = 4x faster growth
- Technology verification: first factory validates the concept

## Regular Supplies from Earth

The base cannot be 100% autonomous. "Vitamins" are needed:

| Category | What exactly | Why not on-site |
|----------|--------------|-----------------|
| Electronics | Control units, sensors | No microchip production |
| Rare earths | Nd, Sm for magnets | Not on Mercury |
| Copper | Continuous casting crystallizers | Deficit on Mercury |
| Tungsten | Dies, cutters | Critical for processing |
| Iridium | MRE anodes | Ultra-rare |
| Gases | Argon, nitrogen | No atmosphere |

### Vitamin Requirements

```
Per factory/year:
- Electronics: ~10 kg (for ~180 robots)
- Dies/cutters: ~3 kg
- MRE anodes: ~4 kg
- Gases: ~10 kg
- Other: ~3 kg
TOTAL: ~30 kg/factory/year
```

### Supply Schedule

| Year | Factories | Vitamins | Add. factories* | Total cargo | Flights** |
|------|-----------|----------|-----------------|-------------|-----------|
| 1 | 25 | 1 t | +10 | ~400 t | 8-20 |
| 2 | 120 | 4 t | +30 | ~1,100 t | 22-55 |
| 3 | 500 | 15 t | +100 | ~3,600 t | 72-180 |
| 4 | 1,000 | 30 t | +200 | ~5,500 t | 110-275 |
| **Total** | | | | **~22,000 t*** | **~550** |

*Including first expeditions (225 t) and +30% reserve.
**Flights: minimum (Starship ~50 t) - maximum (Falcon Heavy ~20 t).

*Additional factories accelerate growth - each factory = +15 robots/month.

### Supply Economics

```
Delivery cost (Starship): ~$100/kg -> $100M for 1000 t
Delivery cost (current): ~$10,000/kg -> $10B for 1000 t

With Starship: year 3 supplies = ~$360M
This is cheap for a planetary-scale project.
```

**Conclusion:** Earth supplies are not a problem. This is <1% of mass produced on Mercury.

## Month 6-7: Mercury Energy Saturation

### Calculation
```
MD: 600 mirrors/day
In 30 days: 18,000 mirrors

Mirror energy (for base, 50% efficiency):
18,000 x 93 MW x 0.5 = 837,000 MW = 837 GW

Base consumption at this point:
- 1 factory: 5 MW
- 1 MD: 40 MW
- Robots, infrastructure: 10 MW
= 55 MW
```

**Excess: 837,000 / 55 = 15,200x**

### Conclusion
**Within first month of MD operation, energy ceases to be a constraint forever.**

Even per day:
```
600 mirrors x 93 MW x 0.5 = 27,900 MW = 27.9 GW
```
This covers base consumption 500 times over.

## Months 5-12: Expansion (with 4 factories)

### Now the Only Constraint - Robot Production

| Resource | Status |
|----------|--------|
| Energy | Infinite (after MD - 13,000x excess) |
| Materials | Infinite (Mercury is rich) |
| **Robots** | **Bottleneck** (60/month for 4 factories) |

### 4 Factory Advantage

```
With 1 factory: 15 robots/month -> slow growth
With 4 factories: 60 robots/month -> 4x faster
```

### Strategy: Build Factories and MDs in Parallel

```
Month 5: 4 factories (60 robots/month) - E2 arrived
Month 6: First MD ready!
Month 7: 8 factories (120 robots/month)
Month 9: 16 factories (240 robots/month)
Month 12: 25 factories (375 robots/month)
```

### Parallel: More MDs

```
Month 6: 1 MD (first!)
Month 8: 3 MDs
Month 10: 6 MDs
Month 12: 12 MDs
```

## Self-Replication: 1 Factory -> ~1650 Factories

**Growth strategy:**
- Each factory produces 15 Gen-2 robots/month
- Robots build new factories and MDs in parallel
- Exponential growth limited only by robot production

**Growth schedule:**
- **Year 1:** 25 factories, 12 MDs (after E2)
- **Year 2:** 120 factories, 80 MDs
- **Year 3:** 500 factories, 400 MDs
- **Year 3.5:** 1000 factories, 800 MDs
- **Year 4:** **~1650 factories, 1000 MDs**

**99% local materials:**
- Robot frames: Al (local)
- Factory structures: Fe (local)
- Mirrors: 4 um Al foil (local)
- Factory domes: silicate composite (local)

**1% import from Earth** ("Vitamins"):
- Electronics: control boards, sensors
- Rare earths: Nd, Sm for magnets
- Copper: for MD coils (critical for conductivity)
- Iridium: MRE anodes

## Why Not Infinite Growth

**Criticism:** "Exponential growth is fantasy. You're just drawing pretty tables."

**Response:** Criticism is valid if the goal is infinite growth for growth's sake. But our goal is finite:

### Project Goal

| Parameter | Value |
|-----------|-------|
| Target power | ~10,000 TW |
| World consumption | 2.3 TW |
| Margin | 4,000x |
| Time to achieve | **3 years** |

**Why 4000x margin?**
- Mars terraforming (magnetic field)
- Interplanetary logistics
- Population and consumption growth (100 years ahead)
- Space industry

### After Year 3: Maintenance Mode

```
Growth STOPS after reaching goal:
- 1000 MDs operating
- Factories switch to repair and replacement
- New mirrors = replace worn ones
- Vitamin supplies continue
```

### Exponential is Tool, Not Goal

| Phase | Years | Mode | Goal |
|-------|-------|------|------|
| Ramp-up | 0-3 | Exponential growth | Reach 1000 MDs |
| Plateau | 3+ | Maintenance | System operation |

**Main conclusion:** We're not building an infinite machine. We're building infrastructure with a finite goal. Exponential is only needed to reach the goal in reasonable time (3 years instead of 30).

## Known Limitations

> **Attention:** This section describes problems requiring solutions.

### Critical Issues

#### 1. Timelines Are Underestimated

| Phase | Planned timeline | Realistic estimate |
|-------|------------------|-------------------|
| R&D | 2 years | **3-4 years** |
| Earth proving ground | 2 years | **3-4 years** |
| Moon proving ground | 2 years | **3-5 years** |
| Mercury to 1000 MDs | 4 years | **5-7 years** |
| **Total** | **10 years** | **14-20 years** |

**Reasons:**
- Each problem in space -> months of waiting
- AI development is unpredictable (Waymo: 15 years, no full autonomy)
- Political delays not accounted for

#### 2. "Leap of Faith" - High Risk

Launching E2 one month after E1 landing (not waiting for full validation):

| Scenario | Consequences |
|----------|--------------|
| E1 successful | 3 months gained |
| E1 failed | E2 useless (~$1-2B lost) |

**E1 failure probability:** 10-30% (first mission to new planet).

### High Issues

#### 3. Next-Generation Super-Heavy Carriers {#next-generation-super-heavy-carriers}

Project depends on carriers with ~$1,000-2,500/kg cost appearing:

| Carrier | Country | Payload capacity | Expected |
|---------|---------|------------------|----------|
| Starship | USA | 150-200 t | 2027-2030 |
| Long March 9 | China | 150 t | 2030+ |
| Yenisei | Russia | 100 t | 2030+ |
| New Glenn | USA | 45 t | 2025-2026 |
| SHLV | India | ~100 t | 2035+ |

| Assumption | Risk |
|------------|------|
| Target price $1,000-1,500/kg by 2030 | Could be $2,500-3,000/kg |
| 100-150 t to LEO | Real capacity may be lower |

**Consequences:** If super-heavy carrier development delays, project shifts 2-3 years. Risk reduced through diversification: multiple countries developing such carriers in parallel.

#### 4. Lunar Proving Ground May Be Insufficient

| Parameter | Moon | Mercury |
|-----------|------|---------|
| Temperature | -180C...+120C | -180C...**+430C** |
| Solar flux | 1.4 kW/m^2^ | **10 kW/m^2^** |
| Radiation | Moderate | **Extreme** |
| Dust | Abrasive | **Abrasive + charged** |

**Risk:** Moon success doesn't guarantee Mercury success.

### Require Research

#### 5. International Cooperation

- Project requires USA, China, Russia, EU, India participation
- Geopolitical situation 2026 - tense
- Sanctions and export controls block technology transfer

**Scenario:** Competition instead of cooperation -> expense duplication, slowdown.

#### 6. Regulatory Barriers

- Laser energy transmission through atmosphere - requires international agreements
- Frequency regulation for billion mirrors - doesn't exist
- Space debris liability - not defined

### Adjusted Timelines

| Scenario | Total time | Comment |
|----------|------------|---------|
| Optimistic | 10-12 years | Everything goes to plan |
| **Baseline** | **14-16 years** | Moderate delays |
| Conservative | 18-25 years | Serious problems |

**Conclusion:** Realistic timeline to 1000 MDs - **14-16 years**, not 10 years.
